page.title: 09Pilgrimages to Glastonbury.
page.content: {Pilgrims}wend their way to{Glastonbury every year. The{Roman Catholic}and {Anglican}Churches stage separate events. Thousands of Pilgrims make their way to the town, which is famed as being "the seat of early Christianity in England". Many climb to the ruined tower of St. Michael's church sited at the top of the Tor. The Anglican Pilgrimage, the larger of the two, is held on the Saturday after {St. John the Baptist's}day. During the morning the town is quickly filled with coaches which jam the roads. Some Pilgrims journey on foot from as far away as Bristol. In the afternoon there is a large and colourful procession which leads from St.John's Church to the{Abbey Ruins.}A service,held in the Abbey grounds is relayed by loudspeakers to the crowds.
